title.narrative: Safhe Jaded: Implementing the Afghan NAP

description.narrative:
The Safhe Jaded: Implementing the Afghan NAP 1325 by linking inclusive security and justice Programme is a three year Programme proposal. It is to be implemented by the Afghan Women#s Educational Center (AWEC), Cordaid and Oxfam Novib, together with a group of local partner organizations including the Afghan Women Judges Association (AWJA), the Hamida Barmaki Organization for the Rule of Law (HBORL), and the Women and Peace Studies Organization (WPSO, formerly the Research Institute for Women, Peace and Security (RIWPS). Other local partner organizations and their grassroots networks and constituencies may also play an indirect or direct role during the course of the Programme.
In accordance with the Netherlands National Action Plan on Women, Peace and Security (2016-2019) and indirect support of the implementation of the Afghan National Action Plan 1325, the Programme aims to contribute to increased security and justice for women and girls in Afghanistan. To do so, it will 1) leverage training and capacity building to both Civil SocietyOrganizations (CSOs) and civil servants around the implementation of the Afghan NAP 1325; 2) contribute to changes in attitudes andbelief that will enable inclusive security and inclusive justice to produce better protection outcomes for women and girls; and 3) advocate around the implementation of laws and policies in favor of inclusive security and justice in Afghanistan.

participating-org.narrative:
The Institute for Women Peace <(>&<)> Security # Afghanistan (registered with MoE)
WPSO is a woman-led initiative conceptualized following the Peace Consultative Jirga in 2010 and established in 2011 to focus on increasing women#s inclusion and leadership in the effort to bring peace and security to Afghanistan. WPSO seeks to build on and strengthen the advocacy campaigns carried out by many other women#s organizations in Kabul to ensure a coordinated and collaborative effort. The unique aspiration of theInstitute is toengage Afghan women and advance their strategic participation to improve social cohesion, restore war-torn communities, and rebuildrelationships at the grassroots and national levels.
The rationale for the establishment of RIWPS is the-overall belief that Afghan women at the grassroots and community levels have important contributions to make to stability and peace, both in their traditional and emerging roles. Those contributions need to be documented and promoted for local and national peace <(>&<)> security efforts to be sustainable. RIWPS will document those contributions of women leaders at the grassroots, empower them with community mobilization and advocacy efforts and connect them to find and negotiate their spaces at the local governance structures as well as national governance structures.
Vision: To advance a new paradigm for peace and security in Afghanistan that is inclusive of women#s perspectives.
Mission: To leverage the knowledge of women leaders in grassroots movements, strengthen capacities, and support research thatwill increase women#s security and the gender-responsiveness of peace building policies, programs and institutions.
Strategic Approach: Research <(>&<)> evidence building on women#s contributions to peace <(>&<)>security; Advocacy through knowledge sharing; Training <(>&<)> empowerment; coordination with WPS stakeholders.
Summary of WPSO activities since inception:
# Sexual and gender-based violence sensitization and tracking capacity building for public healthpractitioners in the Ministry of Public Health <(>&<)> HPIC(April-June 2012)
# Facilitation <(>&<)> editing of National Strategy for Inclusive Peace with Afghanistan Civil Society Network for Peace, in partnership with Oxfam GB (June 2012): WPSO worked with Nonmembers and solicited their inputs and perspective around CSOs role in community based peace building that formed the National Strategy.
# Capacity building <(>&<)> mobilization of female PPCs for women's inclusion in peace <(>&<)> reintegration for the female membersof the Provincial Peace Councils (July # December 2012): RIWPS worked with HPC and PPCs in 25 provinces and mobilized around 50 female members of PPC to influence the provincial level reintegration processes.
# Evidence Building <(>&<)> research onwomen's rights and human rights abuses by the Afghan Local Police (ALP) in Kunduz <(>&<)> surrounding provinces (July-December 2012)
# Review <(>&<)> editing of the Women's Guide to Security Sector Reform from Afghanistan women's rights perspective <(>&<)> WPSO experience with The Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of the Armed Forces (DCAF) and The Institute for Inclusive Security (July-August 2012)
# Research brief produced based on focus group discussions and activist interviews on Afghan women <(>&<)> the security transition in Afghanistan, published with International Civil Society Action Network following a consultation process with over 30 women organizations all around the country (Aug-December 2012)
# Conducted people#s perceptions survey commissioned by USIPin partnership with Institute of Rethinking Policies on the Opinion Leaders perspectives around peace and reconciliation process (July # September 2012)
# Conducted a baseline study on EVAW through a participatory action research on the implementationof Elimination of Violence against Women Law in 4 provinces including Kabul, Hirat, Balkh and Helmand. (December 2012-April 2013)
# Civil Society Dialogue with HPC on Roadmap: WPSO has been collecting inputs and perspectives of communities, traditional and emerging leaders on the Peace Roadmap and started sharing with the HPC through a series of ongoing Dialogue sessions. (April # December 2013)
Currently WPSO-Afghanistan is working with local CSOs on community-based inclusive peace building interventions.One of the key programs is RIWPS#s partnership with Oxfam-GB that is working with 3 other local CSOs on an inclusive peace building strategy <(>&<)> Provincial Peace Hearings on creating Regional and national mobilization of youth, elders, media sector and ulema groups around a common vision for sustainable peace process.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
